Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Gymnosperms on the Tree of Life: Resolving the Phylogeny of Seed Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
AToL for Gymnosperms: Resolving the Phylogeny of Seed Plants
An award is made to Sarah Mathews (Lead PI), Jianhua Li (Co-PI), Harvard University; Reed S. Beaman (PI), Nico Cellinese (Co-PI), Yale University; Christopher S. Campbell (PI), University of Maine; Richard C. Cronn (Collaborator), USDA Forest Service; Sean W. Graham (Co-PI), University of British Columbia; Stefanie M. Ickert-Bond (PI), University of Alaska; Dean G. Kelch (PI), University of California-Berkeley and California State Herbarium; Aaron I. Liston (PI), Oregon State University; Linda A. Raubeson (PI), Central Washington University; Gar W. Rothwell (PI), Gene Mapes (Co-PI), Ohio University; Andrea E. Schwarzbach (PI), University of Texas-Brownsville; Dennis W. Stevenson (PI), New York Botanical Garden; Ruth A. Stockey (Co-PI), University of Alberta to construct sequence-based phylogenetic hypotheses for all living gymnosperms and for seed plants overall, and morphology-based hypotheses to include ALL living species of gymnosperms (conifers, cycads, Gingko, and Gnetales) including examples from the fossil record, along with exemplar angiosperms (flowering plants). Nuclear, plastid and mitochondrial sequences will be utilized in the analysis along with the morphological characters to allow the rich record of fossil gymnosperms to be included. All of the data (molecular, morphological, voucher, etc.) will be submitted to standardized and accessible databases through an enhanced version of the web-based informatics tool TOLKIN (Tree Of Life Knowledge and Information Network, www.tolkin.org). The evolution of the seed marks one of the most important innovations in the history of land plants and led to greater mating control and to enhanced survival and dispersal capabilities. Seed bearing plants dominate the landscape; today, forests and grasslands are among our most important resources. Understanding the origin(s) of seeds is basic to understanding seed plant phylogeny. Obtaining the needed phylogenetic framework is not a trivial undertaking and the multi-faceted approach is designed to address the inherent complexity of the problem, incorporating approaches not considered by all projects (e.g., including all gymnosperms, serious attention to the fossil data). While phylogenetic inference will be the main focus of the project, data will bear significantly on the understanding of historic patterns of biotic change at the global level, and will provide insight into the origins of many important plant traits, including those that are the basis of breeding programs in horticulture and forestry. In addition to training students, workshops for K-12 teachers will be held at several botanic gardens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seed plants, gymnosperms (Ginkgo, conifers, cycads and gnetophytes) and flowering plants, comprise most of the Earth’s terrestrial vegetation.  These plants provide us with food, clothes, medicines, and building materials, as well as habitat for us and all other animals. The evolutionary relationships among these plant groups are not well understood and relationships within the gymnosperms have not been well explored.  Understanding relationships of organisms is a fundamental type of knowledge that guides many other types of basic and applied research.

The Collaborative Research: Gymnosperms on the Tree of Life: Resolving the Phylogeny of Seed Plants project (GToL) was designed to remedy these deficiencies of understanding. The goals of the overall project, undertaken by 15 PIs, representing 13 institutions, were to sample all extant gymnosperm species for three DNA regions and for morphological characteristics, and then use the sampled variation to determine evolutionary relationships. In addition, for representative species, we worked to sequence whole plastid genomes (i.e., plastomes) and used that DNA data to investigate the evolutionary relationships of seed plants. In the Raubeson lab, we were participating in this last aspect of the project.

To obtain platome sequence, we decided to use a then new next-generation sequencing approach, for which we enriched for chloroplast DNA using a PCR strategy.  We amplified the chloroplast DNA in 3-5,000 base pair overlapping fragments; then we pooled the fragments, generated Illumina libraries, obtained Illumina reads, and assembled the nearly complete plastome sequences bioinformatically.  The gymnosperms are divergent enough that each clade needed its own PCR primer strategy.  One of the contributions from the Raubeson lab to the project as a whole was to develop primer strategies and provide reference plastome sequences for Ephedra, Cupressaceae, Podocarpaceae, Taxaceae, Araucariaceae, and cycads. We also produced PCR pools and libraries for some of the sampled taxa in each of these clades.

After generating sequence data, we conducted analyses in several different groups of gymnosperms, usually in collaboration with other members of the GToL group.  For example, we worked with Steffi Ickert-Bond, University of Alaska, to investigate relationships of species in Ephedra (Mormon Tea). At CWU, we designed the PCR strategy, prepared about half of the PCR pools and all of the libraries, and then participated in the data analysis.  We found that the extant species of Ephedra are the result of a more recent radiation (Paleogene), than that tracked by fossils (Cretaceous), suggesting that long distance dispersal contributed to the modern day distribution of the Ephedra species. Long distance dispersal over oceans is also suggested within the more recent radiations of Gnetum, Araucariaceae and Juniperus. 

In Araucariaceae, we sequenced plastomes from 27 of the 40 species.  Our results indicate that major divisions within the family were driven by vicariance as their timing correlates well to that of the break up of Gondwana.  Some more recent radiations to ocean island chains are inferred to take place via dispersal. Because we were working with mostly complete chloroplast genomes, we had much more sequence data than earlier work in this group, and were thus able to obtain better estimates of divergence dates. Interestingly, we date the divergence of Agathis australis to correspond to the splitting of New Zealand from Australia.  This implies that New Zealand was not completely submerged during the Oligocene.

Training is an important part of my research lab.  Twelve undergraduates, 4 master’s students and 1 postdoctoral fellow were involved with me in the project, and received training in specialized molecular laboratory techniques and computational bioinformatics and phylogenetic approaches, as well as general skills such as scientific thinking, communication, ethics, and record keeping.  All lab members had the opportunity to present their work at scientific meetings and most have been or will be co-authors on publications. Three former lab members have gone on to earn their PhDs in biology, 5 have gone on into the health professions, 2 have taken jobs in biotechnology and 2 have agency jobs.  I have also used aspects of the research as class projects in courses such as Genomics for Teachers and our major’s genetics course.

We have found that gymnosperms are continuing to evolve and to speciate.  It is a common misconception that gymnosperms are evolutionary relicts, having been “outcompeted” by flowering plants.  Although it is very true that the flowering plants are the dominant group of land plant, gymnosperms are very successful in certain environments. Due to their biology, gymnosperms may be more constrained in habit and habitat than angiosperms, but the extant species are not archaic. Understanding the patterns of gymnosperm relationships (relationships among and between groups and the correlation of branching with geologic time and events) provides insight into evolutionary mechanisms, which then can guide our understanding of plant functional traits, community assembly rules, and a wide variety of other biological processes.
